sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
This record can be found on pages 159-161 of REED: Inns of Court, Vol. 1
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

row.cell:
Ordinatum est ad hoc parliamentum quod festum Natalis
Domini solempniter (non grande) celerabiturfor celebrabitur Et quod
Communie continuabuntur vsque ad proximum Terminum
et allocatur hic commorantibus vna biga Carbonum et
quadraginta solidi pro salario Musicorum ante hac consueto,
Et preteria allocatur pro Communijs

At this parliament it was ordered that the feast of Christmas will be celebrated solemnly, not grandly, and that commons will be continued up until next term; and one cart-load of coals is allowed for those remaining here and 40s for the musicians’ salary (as has been) previously customary, and in addition allowed for the commons

div.ab: Iones. Inigo armiger admissus Inigo Iones armiger admissus est in Societatem Medij Templi Specialiter ex assensu Roberti Davyes armigeri Modo Lectoris et aliorum Magistrorum de Banco

Jones, Inigo, esquire, admitted Inigo Jones, esquire, has been admitted specially into the society of the Middle Temple by the assent of Robert Davies, esquire, reader at present, and (by the assent) of other benchers.

A generall Taxacion fforasmvch as at this tyme the howse standeth indebted in dyvers somes of money amounting in the whole to the some of six hundred poundes and moore, wheareof a greate parte of the said some of six hundred poundes ys owing vnto dyvers artificers in this Cittye, such as are not able to forbeare their money but to their greate losse or vndoing, ffor avoyding of all such inconveniences which maye heereafter grow by reason of the said debt, The infra hic. b. Masters of the Bench have at this present parliament decreed and so ordered that there shalbe forthwith another taxacion presently levyed thorowgh owt this howse, videlicet everye one of the Masters of the Bench to paye iij li., and everye one of the Masters of the vtterbarr to paye xl s., and everye other gentleman of this ffellowshipp to paye xx s.
Provided that all such gentlemen of this howse that have bynn admytted since the first daye of Easter Tearme last, and all others to be admitted heereafter shalbe free from this tax./

Taxacion Whereas at the parliament holden the xjth daye of this instant moneth of Iune, Yt was then ordered by all the Masters of the Bench, that there showld be an other taxacion presently levyed thorowgh owt this howse videlicet every every one of the Masters of the Bench to paye iij li., and every one of the Masters of the vtterbarr to paye xl s., and every other gentleman of supra hic. a. this ffellowshipp to paye xx s., Synce which tyme the Masters of the Bench vnderstanding the vnwillingnes of the gentlemen to be taxed at such greate somes, and the saide Masters of the Bench willing to ease them as mvche as in them lyeth, have ordered that wheareas the Masters of the Bench weare taxed at iij li. a peece, to be now but l s. a peece which ys forth with to be payde, and everye vtterbarrister which was to paye xl s. ys now to paye but xxx s. the one half thereof to be payde before sundaye next, and the other half to be payde before the ffeastdaye of all Saintes next comming, And every other gentlemen of this ffellowshipp which was, to paye xx s. a peece ys nowe to paye but xv s. the one half thereof to be payde before Sundaye next, and the other half to be payde before the ffeastdaye of all Sayntes next commyng as aforesayde, and all gentlemen that are Attorneys or practisers of the house to paye xx s. a peece, the one half thereof to be payde before before Sundaye next and the other half thereof to be paide before the feast of all Sayntes next commyng as aforesayde, And further wheareas dy...rs gentlemen of this ffellowshipp have vsually come into Commons in the vacacion tymes, and not in the Tearme tymes onelye to avoyde the payment of duetyes. Yt ys therefore further ordered that all such gentlemen that now are in Commones, or that shall come into Commons at anye tyme heereafter, shall not goe owt of Commons before they have payde all such some or somes by them due as aforesayde./

infra 67 .b. Whereas Edward Powell gentlemen one of the ffellowes of this howse hathe of his voluntary mynde lent vnto the ffellowshipp of this howse the towardes the defraying of the chardg of the late Maske the some of fiftye poundes curraunt money, ffor repayment whereof the Masters of the Benche have at this present parliament with one consent decreed and so ordered that the saide some of fyftye poundes shalbe repayd vnto the saide Edward Powell his executors or assignes at the ende of six monethes next after the date of this present parliament./

Baldwines, Barkers, & Bluntes bond discharged And further wheareas Richard Baldwin, ffrauncis Barker, & Arthur Blunt, Officers of this howse at ye instance of the right worshipfull the Masters of the Bench of this howse, doe stand ioyntly and seuerally bound in one obligacion bearing date the xvth daye of ffebruary last past vnto Sir Thomas Temple of Stauntonbury in the Countye of Buckinghamshire knight in the some of fower hundred poundes of lawfull money of England, with condicion for the payment of two hundred and fifteene poundes one the xviijth daye of November next ensuing, as by the same obligacion and condicion more at large yt doth and maye appeare, which money was imployed towardes the defraying of the charge of the late maske, Now the Masters of the Bench have at this present parliament with one consent and agreement, decreed & soe ordered that the saide of somme of CCxv li. shalbe repayde vnto the sayde Sir Thomas Temple his executors or assignes one the saide xviijth daye of November and according to the tenor and effect of the sayde obligacion & condicion,
